query: relationship between liquidity increase and risk assets
what_happened: The Liquidity Index (red line) shows a massive spike during Covid in 2020, peaked in early 2022, then declined sharply through 2022-2023. After Fed action following the SVB crisis and the Yen Carry Trade blow up in 2024, liquidity stabilized. However, by late 2024/early 2025 (Liberation Day and Gov't Shutdown/Repo Crisis), liquidity has dropped significantly while the S&P 500 (black line) continued to rise, creating a major divergence between liquidity conditions and equity prices.
interpretation: Despite abundant liquidity historically, a dangerous divergence has emerged where the S&P 500 continues rallying while the Liquidity Index declines. This suggests investors have shifted from liquidity-driven investing (buying dips based on liquidity conditions) to Fed signal-driven investing since 2022, betting more on Fed guidance than fundamentals. This disconnect indicates potential market vulnerability, as equity prices are rising without corresponding liquidity support, suggesting the market may be overextended and relying primarily on Fed expectations rather than actual monetary conditions.
extracted_data_full: {"source": "Real Investment Advice", "data_source": "Federal Reserve Balance Sheet (Fed B/S), Treasury General Account (TGA), and Reverse Repo Program (RRP)", "asset_class": "Equities", "used_data": "Liquidity Index (calculated from Fed B/S + TGA + RRP) compared against S&P 500 Composite Price Index from January 2019 to January 2025", "what_happened": "The Liquidity Index (red line) shows a massive spike during Covid in 2020, peaked in early 2022, then declined sharply through 2022-2023. After Fed action following the SVB crisis and the Yen Carry Trade blow up in 2024, liquidity stabilized. However, by late 2024/early 2025 (Liberation Day and Gov't Shutdown/Repo Crisis), liquidity has dropped significantly while the S&P 500 (black line) continued to rise, creating a major divergence between liquidity conditions and equity prices.", "interpretation": "Despite abundant liquidity historically, a dangerous divergence has emerged where the S&P 500 continues rallying while the Liquidity Index declines. This suggests investors have shifted from liquidity-driven investing (buying dips based on liquidity conditions) to Fed signal-driven investing since 2022, betting more on Fed guidance than fundamentals. This disconnect indicates potential market vulnerability, as equity prices are rising without corresponding liquidity support, suggesting the market may be overextended and relying primarily on Fed expectations rather than actual monetary conditions."}
